title: AI-driven reinsurance capacity for Specialty and P&C cedants (10-year program)
description: Leverage IHC–RIQ’s preferred reinsurance partnership targeting USD 500M in premiums over the next decade, with AI-augmented underwriting across complex Specialty and Property & Casualty lines. RIQ (launched by IHC with BlackRock and Lunate; ADGM-based and progressing toward FSRA authorization) can provide quota share and excess-of-loss capacity to primary insurers and MGAs in MENA and high-growth regions.
example: Example 1: A GCC commercial property insurer cedes 25% quota share on an industrial property portfolio with USD 320M annual GWP. RIQ provides USD 80M capacity, uses satellite and hazard data to refine flood/fire pricing, and structures a cat XoL layer to protect frequency and severity. Value: expands the cedant’s underwriting capacity and stabilizes combined ratio while RIQ grows premium toward its USD 500M target. Example 2: A Southeast Asia motor telematics MGA seeks a 20% quota share plus a 110%–120% aggregate stop-loss on USD 200M GWP. RIQ’s AI uses trip-level telematics to segment risk and improves rate adequacy by 3–5 pts. Value: MGA scales faster with disciplined capital; RIQ diversifies into profitable, data-rich motor risk.
roadmap: Identify priority cedants/MGAs in Specialty and P&C; execute NDAs
Set up secure data room; ingest 3–5 years of exposure, premium, and claims data
Run AI-risk modeling; co-develop pricing and portfolio selection
Structure treaties (QS/XoL), wordings, collateral, and security terms
Obtain required regulatory clearances (FSRA and local where applicable)
Bind capacity; implement quarterly performance reviews and model recalibration
source_name: IHC and RIQ Announce Strategic 10-year Alliance Anchored by Over USD 500 Million in Reinsurance Premiums

title: Structured reinsurance for corporates and captives (aggregate stop-loss and parametric)
description: IHC’s alliance with RIQ focuses on intelligent, capital-efficient risk transfer. Non-insurance corporates (including IHC portfolio companies and peers) can structure captive-backed aggregate stop-loss or parametric covers for supply-chain, property, and climate exposures, using RIQ’s AI-native pricing.
example: Example 1: A UAE regional logistics operator forms an ADGM captive and partners with RIQ for a 3-year aggregate stop-loss: captive retains first USD 20M; RIQ covers next USD 50M at 115% loss ratio trigger across cargo, property damage, and business interruption. Value: earnings volatility protection and improved bankability for financing expansions. Example 2: A MENA renewable energy developer purchases a parametric wind/irradiance cover for 1 GW of assets. RIQ uses satellite/SCADA data; payout triggers at wind speed/irradiance shortfalls that reduce production by >8%. Value: stabilizes cash flows, enhances project finance terms.
roadmap: Feasibility study for captive or fronted structure; select ADGM or local domicile
Collect loss and operational data; define triggers (aggregate or parametric)
RIQ AI modeling to size retention, attachment, and limits
Finalize wording, collateral, and fronting (if needed) and seek FSRA/local approvals
Bind multi-year program; integrate real-time data feeds for monitoring
Quarterly performance reviews; adjust triggers/limits as portfolio evolves
source_name: IHC and RIQ Announce Strategic 10-year Alliance Anchored by Over USD 500 Million in Reinsurance Premiums

title: Data and sensor partnerships to power AI underwriting
description: RIQ’s platform relies on advanced data modeling and AI-augmented underwriting. Technology companies can supply high-frequency risk signals (satellite imagery, IoT, cyber threat intel, building sensors) to improve pricing, selection, and event response for Specialty and P&C lines.
example: Example 1: A satellite analytics provider integrates flood depth and wildfire spread models into RIQ’s pricing API for MENA industrial risks. Commercial model: per-risk scoring fee plus loss-based gainshare; expected 2–4 pt improvement in loss ratio for targeted segments. Example 2: A fleet telematics platform shares driver behavior and ADAS utilization for 50,000 vehicles insured by cedants using RIQ capacity. RIQ adjusts ceding commissions by safety score; fleets receive premium credits tied to score improvements.
roadmap: Define priority perils/lines; issue data RFP with technical and commercial terms
Integrate data via secure APIs; validate against historical losses
Run A/B pricing pilots on selected cedants/portfolios
Operationalize data contracts (SLAs, uptime, privacy, localization)
Embed scores into underwriting rules and facultative referrals
Measure impact quarterly; expand to additional geographies/perils
source_name: IHC and RIQ Announce Strategic 10-year Alliance Anchored by Over USD 500 Million in Reinsurance Premiums

title: ILS and sidecar capital vehicles with BlackRock/Lunate distribution
description: Backed by over USD 1B in equity commitments and aiming to write up to USD 10B annually, RIQ can scale via insurance-linked securities (ILS) and sidecars. BlackRock and Lunate can help seed and distribute vehicles to institutional investors seeking uncorrelated returns.
example: Example 1: Launch a USD 300M property cat sidecar domiciled in ADGM, seeded by RIQ portfolios; BlackRock distributes to global investors, with quarterly NAV, target net return 8–12% and low correlation to equities. Example 2: Issue a USD 100M parametric cyclone bond covering GCC windstorms, with satellite-based windfield triggers. Value: diversifies RIQ capital stack and offers investors transparent, rules-based exposure.
roadmap: Define target perils/lines and risk-return profile for ILS/sidecar
Structure SPV and offering docs in ADGM; appoint administrators and auditors
Secure initial seed from IHC/partners; obtain FSRA and securities approvals
Onboard investors via BlackRock/Lunate channels; close first capital raise
Allocate to RIQ-originated treaties; implement real-time risk reporting
Scale with additional vintages; consider multi-peril funds over time
source_name: IHC and RIQ Announce Strategic 10-year Alliance Anchored by Over USD 500 Million in Reinsurance Premiums

title: Fronting carrier partnerships for rapid market entry pre/post-authorization
description: As RIQ advances its FSRA authorization, partnering with rated fronting carriers in target jurisdictions enables immediate issuance of local policies while retroceding risk to RIQ. This accelerates rollout of Specialty and P&C solutions aligned with the Abu Dhabi hub strategy.
example: Example 1: GCC motor and SME property: a locally licensed insurer fronts policies and cedes 90% QS to RIQ with funds-withheld collateral and trust account. Value: immediate market access with compliant policy issuance. Example 2: EU specialty lines: an A-rated EU front issues professional indemnity and cyber; RIQ takes 70% quota share and purchases EU cat XoL protection to meet local solvency expectations.
roadmap: Map priority countries/lines; shortlist rated fronting partners
Negotiate fronting fees, collateral terms, claims handling, and audit rights
Draft treaty wordings and TPA arrangements; align on regulatory filings
Pilot limited portfolios; monitor loss emergence and service SLAs
Scale to multi-line, multi-country fronts; optimize capital and retrocession
Transition selected books to direct RIQ paper post-FSRA authorization where feasible
source_name: IHC and RIQ Announce Strategic 10-year Alliance Anchored by Over USD 500 Million in Reinsurance Premiums

title: Buy-and-build M&A: acquiring MGAs, niche reinsurers, and analytics firms
description: RIQ signaled a global buy-and-build strategy to scale intelligently. Owners of profitable MGAs, specialty reinsurance platforms, and risk analytics companies can approach RIQ/IHC for acquisition or joint ventures to accelerate growth and distribution.
example: Example 1: Acquire a London-based marine cargo/stock-throughput MGA with ~USD 150M GWP and a 5-year average combined ratio of 92%. RIQ supplies capacity, adds AI pricing, and expands into MENA port logistics. Example 2: Majority investment in a cyber risk analytics startup providing attack-surface scoring used to underwrite cyber reinsurance, integrating its models into RIQ’s engine.
roadmap: Build target pipeline with bankers and founders; set screening metrics (profitability, data richness, team)
Conduct diligence (loss triangles, exposure management, governance, tech stack)
Structure deals (earn-outs tied to combined ratio and growth)
Integration plan: bind capacity, migrate pricing tools, unify compliance/reporting
Execute cross-sell via RIQ cedant network; track post-close synergies
Establish retro/ILS support to scale acquired books
source_name: IHC and RIQ Announce Strategic 10-year Alliance Anchored by Over USD 500 Million in Reinsurance Premiums

title: Claims and TPA automation partnerships for Specialty and P&C
description: RIQ’s AI-native infrastructure can extend to claims. TPAs, insurtechs, and drone/imagery vendors can integrate to automate FNOL, triage, and fraud detection for cedants and corporate programs, improving LAE and customer experience.
example: Example 1: Property claims triage: a drone/imagery vendor assesses post-storm roof damage for 5,000 SME properties in the GCC; RIQ funds the service via a per-claim fee and ties ceding commission uplifts to faster cycle times. Example 2: Marine cargo: an IoT seal provider flags tamper events in transit; TPA rules auto-initiate claims with documentation, reducing average claim closure time by 30%.
roadmap: Select high-frequency claim types per line (property, cargo, motor)
Evaluate vendors; run pilots with agreed KPIs (cycle time, leakage)
Integrate APIs with RIQ/cedant systems; set data sharing and privacy terms
Deploy in production across selected cedants; monitor SLA and savings
Expand to additional perils; embed fraud analytics and subrogation tools
Feed closed-claim learnings back into pricing models
source_name: IHC and RIQ Announce Strategic 10-year Alliance Anchored by Over USD 500 Million in Reinsurance Premiums
